channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: Prof. Sam Lawler
item.description: I just got back from an off-grid cheese-making and goat herding workshop. It was AMAZING. It sounds ridiculous, but it was almost a religious experience. Everyone there was so passionate about nature and how to utilize naturally occurring healthy microbes to make incredibly delicious, healthy food. It is really hard to not just look at my inbox today, take my goats, and walk back into the woods...

item.title: Amy Orsborn
item.description: Like the Oregon trail, but for getting a Ph.D.: https://research.wmz.ninja/projects/phd/index.htmlI simultaneously really do and really don't want to see what the version of this game would be like for starting a lab as a PI üòÖ‚Äã

item.title: Laura Helmuth
item.description: This is awesome: cobalt comes from thermonuclear supernovae and core-collapse supernovae. Where painters' favorite pigments come from: https://scientificamerican.com/article/some-of-earths-most-famous-art-started-with-stardust/

item.title: StefanThinks
item.description: This guy keeps complaining about how all the letters in the word ‚Äúbuild‚Äù are not pronounced and I finally had to tell him ‚Äúhey, look, i don't care, that‚Äôs a u problem.‚Äù

item.title: Alex Holcombe
item.description: "I explained that we re-did their experiment 50 times and never got their result. He said they'd done it six times and got this result once, but put it in the paper because it made the best story." -G. Begley, 2012 https://reason.com/2012/04/03/can-most-cancer-research-be-trusted/

item.title: Bread and Circuses

item.title: NowWeAreAllTom
item.description: Human beings were never meant to be on a single social media platform for life. Archaeological evidence tells us our earliest ancestors hopped from platform to platform, following the migrations of the influencer herds, moving on when the soil was too depleted to grow new discourse

item.title: Stephen Mathesonüåµüå≤
item.description:
The **Behind the paper** series at the #PLOSBiologue blog at #plosbiology @PLOSBiology is always inspiring and interesting. The newest is about findings in extramedullary hematopoiesis in tumors and tells about how Derek Barisas (MD/PhD student at WashU School of Medicine) nurtured the project through the pandemic‚Äîthe lab shut down 3 months after he started.https://biologue.plos.org/2023/07/05/tumors-produce-factors-that-promote-extramedullary-hematopoiesis/Paper: https://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.3001746#cancerbiology
#behindthepaper
#scienceblogging 1/2

item.title: KB Leecaster
item.description:
Professor Katharine Hayhoe
@kathhayhoe posted some good advice today:If you‚Äôve convinced yourself that we‚Äôre doomed and there‚Äôs nothing anyone can do about climate:‚ùå Stop doom-scrolling & get off social mediaüò≥ Don‚Äôt attack or hinder others doing their best to helpüêæ Adopt a pet in need of a homeüå≥ Spend as much time as you can in nature

‚ù§Ô∏è Focus on love

item.title: Micro SF/F by O. Westin
item.description:
The swordsmith inhaled sharply.
"Is it bad?" the Hero asked.
"This blade can't be repaired."
"But it's the Blade of Fate!"
"Sorry."
"It's destined to help me kill the Dark Lord!"
"Old Runsy?"
"Runsy?"
"I went to school with him. Did you know he's mortally allergic to cats?"
#MicroFiction #TootFic #SmallStories

item.title: Cian O‚ÄôDonnell
item.description:
@schoppik @kevinbolding üòú there is definitely a perceived pecking order in ‚Äúgeneral importance‚Äù of sensory modalities in neuroscience, I‚Äôm going to take a stab at:
1. Vision
2. Audition
3. Somatosensation
4. Olfaction
5. Gustation
6. All the other weird stuff

item.title: Yohan John ü§ñüß†
item.description: What a wanker."Geoffrey Hinton went on a media tour to ‚Äòsound the alarm‚Äô about AI after quitting Google earlier this year. When a CNN journalist asked if he wished he had stood behind previous whistleblowers such as Timnit Gebru when she was forced out of Google (over the Stochastic Parrots paper), he said that ‚Äútheir concerns aren‚Äôt as existentially serious as the idea of these things getting more intelligent than us and taking over.‚Äù"https://medium.com/@emilymenonbender/talking-about-a-schism-is-ahistorical-3c454a77220f#AI #ML

item.title: Luke Drury

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: A fun paper with @aha_momentum: https://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01499 Dendrites are quite similar in lots of ways to actual trees. There may be reasons for that. Probably arxiv is the final location for this article so have fun with it if you like that kind of analysis.

item.title: Leonido
item.description: "Universities of the World, Join the Fediverse!"Please check out and share this call to action with your university officials: https://netzpolitik.org/2023/a-call-to-action-universities-of-the-world-into-the-fediverse/#fediverse #mastodon

item.title: Yohan John ü§ñüß†
item.description: Michael Levin: "The reason cancer‚Äôs not a problem in today‚Äôs robotics is because we build with dumb parts.[...] Whereas in biology, it‚Äôs a multi-scale architecture where every level has goals, and there‚Äôs pros and cons to this." https://nautil.us/the-biologist-blowing-our-minds-323905/In our new paper on "proxy failure" (Goodhart's Law) we touch on the fascinating issue of hierarchies of goal-seeking agents.https://doi.org/10.1017/S0140525X23002753
